awd_titl_txt: Houston - Louis Stokes STEM Pathways and Research Alliance
awd_abstract_narration:
Technical Description

Houston- Louis Stokes STEM Pathways and Research Alliance

In this proposal, Texas Southern University (HBCU), Texas State University (HSI), the University of Houston (HSI), the University of Houston-Downtown (MI/HSI), and the University of Houston-Clear Lake (HSI) will form the Louis Stokes STEM Pathways and Research Alliance (H-LSAMP). The H-LSAMP program was assembled to significantly increase the number of underrepresented minority students who earn a baccalaureate degree in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields, bringing our graduation numbers in line with the population we serve. In this proposal, the H-LSAMP STEM Pathways and Research Alliance proposes to fund new efforts in individual student retention and progression to baccalaureate degrees, transfer programs from community colleges, high-quality undergraduate research experiences, and seamless transitions into STEM graduate programs. 

Our program aims to increase the number, quality, and diversity of undergraduates successfully entering and completing graduate school as well as selecting careers in the exciting and important research areas across the STEM disciplines. Upon completion of the award period, the H-LSAMP program will have provided the opportunity for all level-one students to participate in research. Further, we project that around 50 percent of the level-one students will move on to professional or graduate school and that minority STEM retention will improve to over 75%. As a STEM Pathways and Research Alliance, we will work toward eliminating the two well-documented causes of attrition in STEM fields at the University level: financial need and academic support.

Intellectual Merit: Based on Tinto's model and our robust collaborative learning community, the alliance will add individual development plans coupled with career explorations to provide scholars with sufficient knowledge and skills to provide for fulfilling employment and success in graduate school. Students are supported using best practices of tutoring, peer-led team learning, and mentored research. 
Broader Impacts: This LSAMP proposal has some of the most ethnically diverse research universities in the country which includes participation from high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, staff, faculty and administrators across all STEM disciplines. Building on programs to improve female representation in STEM, and with a mix of all races, this Alliance serves as a model that can be replicated at HSI, MSI, and HBCUs nationwide. The H-LSAMP program has had tremendous success in developing and graduating a quality UREP STEM workforce and projects to continue its nation leading growth during the next five years. Our program works to identify recruitment and retention methodologies that can be scaled and replicated nationally. Our program will provide new PLTL course material, summer bridge modifications to accelerate UREP STEM success, demonstrate the use of IDPs and career awareness to enhance long-term student success, and populate the countries PhD programs with quality UREP STEM future leaders.

Non-Technical Description

Houston- Louis Stokes STEM Pathways and Research Alliance 

In this proposal, Texas Southern University (HBCU), Texas State University (HSI), the University of Houston (HSI), the University of Houston-Downtown (MI/HSI), and the University of Houston-Clear Lake (HSI) will form the Louis Stokes STEM Pathways and Research Alliance (H-LSAMP). The H-LSAMP program was assembled to significantly increase the number of underrepresented minority students who earn a baccalaureate degree in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields, bringing our graduation numbers in line with the population we serve. In this proposal, the H-LSAMP STEM Pathways and Research Alliance proposes to fund new efforts in individual student retention and progression to baccalaureate degrees, transfer programs from community colleges, high-quality undergraduate research experiences, and seamless transitions into STEM graduate programs. 

Our program aims to increase the number, quality, and diversity of undergraduates successfully entering and completing graduate school as well as selecting careers in the exciting and important research areas across the STEM disciplines. Upon completion of the award period, the H-LSAMP program will have provided the opportunity for all level-one students to participate in research. Further, we project that around 50 percent of the level-one students will move on to professional or graduate school and that minority STEM retention will improve to over 75%.  As a STEM Pathways and Research Alliance, we will work toward eliminating the two well-documented causes of attrition in STEM fields at the University level: financial need and academic support.

Intellectual Merit: Based on Tinto's model and our robust collaborative learning community, the alliance will add individual development plans coupled with career explorations to provide scholars with sufficient knowledge and skills to provide for fulfilling employment and success in graduate school. Students are supported using best practices of tutoring, peer-led team learning, and mentored research. 

Broader Impacts: This LSAMP proposal has some of the most ethnically diverse research universities in the country, which includes participation from high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, staff, faculty and administrators across all STEM disciplines. Building on programs to improve female representation in STEM, and with a mix of all races, this Alliance serves as a model that can be replicated at HSI, MSI, and HBCUs nationwide. The H-LSAMP program has had tremendous success in developing and graduating a quality UREP STEM workforce and projects to continue its nation leading growth during the next five years. Our program works to identify recruitment and retention methodologies that can be scaled and replicated nationally. Our program will provide new PLTL course material, summer bridge modifications to accelerate UREP STEM success, demonstrate the use of IDPs and career awareness to enhance long-term student success, and populate the countries PhD programs with quality UREP STEM future leaders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Houston Louis Stokes STEM Pathways and Research Alliance is led by Texas Southern University (HBCU) and is comprised of Texas State University (HIS), University of Houston (HIS), University of Houston Clear Lake (HIS), and the University of Houston-Downtown (MI/HIS). The H-LSAMP program was assembled to significantly increase the number of underrepresented minority students who earn baccalaureate degrees in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields bringing our graduation numbers in line with the population we serve.

The Alliance works to improve student retention and progression to STEM baccalaureate degrees, through a range of activities that include summer bridge programs, supplementary instruction, mentoring, tutoring, career development activities, and access to undergraduate research experiences.  Schools in the H-LSAMP Alliance work with our local community colleges to help students transfer seamlessly from the community college LSAMP programs to the four-year college LSAMP programs, creating a supportive pipeline for students from start to finish.  The H-LSAMP strives to eliminate two well-documented causes of attrition in STEM fields: financial need and academic support. The program is open to all students with recruiting efforts focused on serving students with the greatest need of the support infrastructure. 

The program aims to increase the number, quality, and diversity of undergraduates successfully completing a bachelor’s degree in STEM to more closely resemble the current minority population of Houston (~67% non-white or Asian) and to raise the number of UREP students completing graduate school and entering STEM professions. Growth in the number STEM bachelor’s degrees awarded by Alliance colleges between 2019 and 2022 grew at a slower pace than previously due to the COVID 19 pandemic, however, the Houston Alliance saw a 0.54% increase from 3488 degrees in 2019 to 3507 in 2022.  Strikingly, the Alliance schools saw a 14.91% increase in degrees awarded to URM students with 1375 awarded in 2019 and 1616 awarded in 2022. With 46.1% of all STEM bachelor’s degrees awarded to URM students, this all-time high indicates these institutions are making strides to improve graduation outcomes for all enrolled students but there is still a gap to address before the graduating population reflects the local demographics.  Over a 17-year period of Alliance work (2005-2020), only 8.5% of the degrees earned by students who were financially supported by the H-LSAMP program at any point in their undergraduate careers were outside of STEM disciplines, indicating a very high STEM retention rate for participating students.

Intellectual Merit

This alliance builds on proven best practices for improving the knowledge base in the areas of Collaborative Learning Communities (CLCs), Peer-Led Team Learning (PLTL), mentoring, individual career development plans, student engagement and social integration to improve student retention and graduation in STEM majors.  A key activity of the H-LSAMP Alliance was the modeling of methods to evaluate the impact of these layered program activities across the member institutions over the last 20 years of the Alliance’s work. The Texas state data systems were leveraged to compare outcomes for H-LSAMP students to non-LSAMP students and to investigate the wide range of factors that impact student success. Impact of the program on wages and participation in the STEM workforce for graduates who remained in Texas were studied. More detailed work is in progress to capture the workforce outcomes more broadly through survey responses of alumni. The social science research team has an impressive list of published journal articles and several under review. The team provides modeling of methods that will benefit other LSAMP alliances as they work to communicate their efforts to the education community.

Broader Impacts

H-LSAMP includes participation from undergraduate students, staff, faculty and administrators at some of the most ethnically diverse research universities in the country. This program works to identify student success methodologies that can be scaled and replicated nationally and has had tremendous success in developing and graduating a quality UREP STEM workforce. The Houston LSAMP program is a model and a resource in longitudinal assessment analysis for long-standing, multidimensional student success programs, contributing to the body of knowledge in the educational research space.

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2025
Modified by: Bobby L Wilson
